source.raw_text:
A Tucked Hang (or Hanging Knee Tuck) primarily targets your core (abs, obliques), hip flexors, and grip strength (forearms), while also engaging the lats and upper back for stability; the movement pattern involves a controlled lift of the knees to the chest (hip flexion/spinal flexion) from a dead hang, requiring isometric strength and control to prevent swinging. [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]  
Muscles Worked 

• Primary: 

    • Rectus Abdominis & Transverse Abdominis: For spinal flexion and core bracing. 
    • Hip Flexors (Iliopsoas): To bring the knees up. 
    • Forearms: For grip endurance. 

• Secondary/Stabilizers: 

    • Latissimus Dorsi (Lats): Engage to keep the body stable and control the descent. 
    • Obliques: For rotational stability (especially in twisting variations) and core bracing. 
    • Scapular Stabilizers (Rhomboids, Traps): To keep shoulders down and packed. 
    • Biceps: Isometrically to stabilize the arms. [1, 2, 3, 5, 6, 7, 8]  

Movement Patterns 

1. Start: Begin in a full dead hang, gripping the bar with palms facing forward (or neutral grip for more lat activation). 
2. Engage: Pull your shoulder blades down (scapular depression) and brace your core, tucking your pelvis slightly. 
3. Lift (Hip & Spinal Flexion): Drive your knees up towards your chest (thighs parallel to the floor or higher), bending at the hips and flexing the spine. 
4. Control: Lower back down slowly and with resistance, preventing your body from swinging like a pendulum. 
5. Core Focus: Think about rounding your spine and bringing your pelvis to your ribs, rather than just pulling with your legs. [1, 2, 3, 6, 9]  

This exercise is excellent for building foundational core and grip strength needed for more advanced calisthenics like L-sits and front levers. [1, 7]
